Isotopes.Name: Protium
Isotopes.Use: Hydrogen gas, fuels, acids, and most organic compounds
Isotopes.Notes: Most common and stable isotope of hydrogen

Isotopes.Name: Deuterium
Isotopes.Use: Used in heavy water, nuclear reactors, and fusion research
Isotopes.Notes: Stable hydrogen isotope with one neutron

Isotopes.Name: Tritium
Isotopes.Use: Used in fusion fuel, luminous paints, and radioluminescent devices

Isotopes.Name: Hydrogen-4
Isotopes.Use: None; observed only in laboratory experiments

Isotopes.Name: Hydrogen-6
Isotopes.Notes: Unstable isotope with a lifetime under 10⁻²² seconds

Isotopes.Name: Hydrogen-7
Isotopes.Use: None; produced in particle accelerators only
Isotopes.Notes: Most neutron-rich and unstable isotope of hydrogen

Isotopes.Name: Lithium-7
Isotopes.Use: Most common lithium isotope, batteries, ceramics

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-9
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Extremely exotic, proton-rich, and highly unstable isotope beyond the proton drip line. Not found in nature.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-10
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: A highly unstable, synthetic isotope of nitrogen that is proton-unbound and decays almost instantaneously.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-11
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: A highly unstable, synthetic isotope of nitrogen. It is proton-unbound and decays almost instantaneously.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-12
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-13
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic radioisotope used in nuclear medicine.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-14
Isotopes.Use: Nitrogen gas, fertilizers, ammonia production, proteins
Isotopes.Notes: One of two stable nitrogen isotopes; the most common.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-15
Isotopes.Use: NMR spectroscopy, isotopic labeling in biochemistry and agriculture
Isotopes.Notes: The other stable nitrogen isotope. Its 1/2 spin is useful for NMR.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-16
Isotopes.Use: Coolant monitoring in pressurized water reactors
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic. Its decay produces high-energy gamma rays.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-17
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic. A known beta-delayed neutron emitter.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-18
Isotopes.Decay_Mode: Beta emission (β⁻), Beta-delayed neutron (β⁻n), Beta-delayed alpha (β⁻α)
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic isotope with multiple complex decay branches.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-19
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-20
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-21
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-22
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic, neutron-rich isotope near the neutron drip line.

Isotopes.Name: Nitrogen-23
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic, very neutron-rich isotope. Decays via multiple neutron emission.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-11
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-12
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-13
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-15
Isotopes.Use: Medical PET imaging (cerebral blood flow, oxygen metabolism)
Isotopes.Notes: Commonly used radioisotope in nuclear medicine.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-16
Isotopes.Use: Water, air, organic compounds, industrial processes
Isotopes.Notes: Most abundant stable isotope of oxygen.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-17
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable oxygen isotope with non-zero spin, making it useful for NMR.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-18
Isotopes.Use: Isotopic tracer (paleoclimatology, biochemistry, hydrology), PET scan precursor (¹⁸F production)
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope, widely used as a tracer.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-19
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-20
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-21
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-22
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-23
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-24
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Synthetic, neutron-rich isotope. Has a 'magic' neutron number (16) in this region.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-25
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Unbound isotope, beyond the neutron drip line.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-26
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Unbound isotope, beyond the neutron drip line.

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-27
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research

Isotopes.Name: Oxygen-28
Isotopes.Use: None outside of basic scientific research
Isotopes.Notes: Unbound isotope, observed in 2023. 'Doubly magic' (Z=8, N=20) but unbound.

Isotopes.Name: Fluorine-17
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Participates in the CNO cycle.

Isotopes.Name: Fluorine-18
Isotopes.Use: Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging, synthesis of radiopharmaceuticals (e.g., FDG)
Isotopes.Notes: Most common radioisotope for PET scans. Commercially important source of positrons.

Isotopes.Name: Fluorine-19
Isotopes.Use: Fluorine-19 NMR spectroscopy, component of pharmaceuticals, fluoropolymers (Teflon), steelmaking, water fluoridation
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable, naturally occurring isotope of fluorine. Fluorine is a monoisotopic element.

Isotopes.Name: Fluorine-26
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Also has an isomer, 26mF.

Isotopes.Name: Fluorine-31
Isotopes.Notes: Heaviest known fluorine isotope. Exhibits beta-delayed multi-neutron emission.

Isotopes.Name: Neon-15
Isotopes.Notes: Proton unbound. Decays via double proton emission.

Isotopes.Name: Neon-16
Isotopes.Notes: Proton unbound. Decays via double proton emission.

Isotopes.Name: Neon-20
Isotopes.Use: Neon signs, cryogenics, refrigerant, gas lasers
Isotopes.Notes: Most abundant stable isotope of neon.

Isotopes.Name: Neon-34
Isotopes.Notes: Heaviest known neon isotope. Exhibits beta-delayed neutron emission.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-18
Isotopes.Notes: Proton unbound. Extremely unstable, decays almost instantly.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-22
Isotopes.Use: Positron source for PET scan calibration, scientific research, medical tracer
Isotopes.Notes: Cosmogenic isotope. Important positron emitter with a relatively long half-life.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-23
Isotopes.Use: Table salt (NaCl), sodium-vapor lamps, chemical industry, nuclear reactor coolant, human nutrition
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable isotope of sodium. Sodium is a monoisotopic element.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-24
Isotopes.Use: Medical tracer (blood flow, tumors), industrial tracer (pipeline leak detection), research
Isotopes.Notes: Cosmogenic isotope. Produced by neutron activation of ²³Na.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-31
Isotopes.Notes: Considered to be a halo nucleus.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-35
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Decay properties are theoretical/estimated.

Isotopes.Name: Sodium-37
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Decay properties are theoretical/estimated.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-19
Isotopes.Notes: Proton unbound. Extremely unstable, decays via double proton emission.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-20
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Exhibits beta-delayed proton emission.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-21
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Exhibits beta-delayed proton emission.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-24
Isotopes.Use: Lightweight structural alloys (aerospace, automotive), electronics, dietary supplement, chemical reactions
Isotopes.Notes: Most abundant stable isotope of magnesium.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-25
Isotopes.Use: Magnesium-25 NMR spectroscopy, tracer in biological/geological studies
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. The only stable magnesium isotope with non-zero spin.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-26
Isotopes.Use: Geological dating (Al-Mg system), medical research (calcium metabolism)
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. It is the daughter product of Aluminum-26, used in radiometric dating of meteorites.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-28
Isotopes.Use: Tracer in chemistry and biology (magnesium transport)
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Longest-lived radioisotope of magnesium.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-31
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Located within the 'island of inversion'.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-32
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. A key nucleus in the 'island of inversion'.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-33
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Also part of the 'island of inversion'.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-38
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Decay properties are not well-known.

Isotopes.Name: Magnesium-40
Isotopes.Notes: Neutron unbound. Decays via double neutron emission. Heaviest known magnesium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Aluminum-26
Isotopes.Use: Radiometric dating of meteorites, cosmogenic isotope studies
Isotopes.Notes: Long-lived cosmogenic radioisotope. Its decay product, ²⁶Mg, is used to date solar system materials.

Isotopes.Name: Aluminum-27
Isotopes.Use: Structural metal (alloys), electrical conductors, kitchenware, construction, reflective coatings
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable isotope of aluminum. Aluminum is a monoisotopic element.

Isotopes.Name: Aluminum-32
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Located at the 'island of inversion'.

Isotopes.Name: Aluminum-36
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope. Decay properties not well-known.

Isotopes.Name: Aluminum-42
Isotopes.Notes: Neutron unbound. Heaviest known aluminum isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Silicon-28
Isotopes.Use: Semiconductor industry (microchips), glass, cement, Avogadro project (kilogram redefinition)
Isotopes.Notes: Most abundant stable isotope of silicon.

Isotopes.Name: Silicon-29
Isotopes.Use: Silicon-29 NMR spectroscopy, quantum computing research
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Useful for NMR as it is the only stable Si isotope with non-zero spin.

Isotopes.Name: Silicon-32
Isotopes.Use: Radiometric dating (oceanography, geology), cosmogenic isotope tracer

Isotopes.Name: Phosphorus-31
Isotopes.Use: Fertilizers (phosphates), DNA/RNA backbone, ATP (energy), chemical industry, P-31 NMR spectroscopy
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable isotope of phosphorus. Phosphorus is a monoisotopic element.

Isotopes.Name: Phosphorus-31
Isotopes.Use: Fertilizers (phosphates), DNA/RNA backbone, ATP (energy), chemical industry, P-31 NMR spectroscopy
Isotopes.Notes: The only stable isotope of phosphorus. Phosphorus is a monoisotopic element.

Isotopes.Name: Phosphorus-33
Isotopes.Use: Biochemical tracer (less energetic alternative to ³²P), DNA sequencing (historical)
Isotopes.Notes: Radioactive isotope used in life sciences.

Name: Chlorine
Abundance: O: 19,400 ppm | A: trace | U: 1 ppm

Isotopes.Name: Scandium-44
Isotopes.Notes: Used as a PET imaging agent, often from a ⁴⁴Ti generator.

Isotopes.Name: Scandium-45
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Aluminum alloys, High-intensity lights, NMR

Isotopes.Name: Titanium-44
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, ⁴⁴Sc generator for PET imaging
Isotopes.Notes: Decays to ⁴⁴Sc, which is used in PET scans.

Isotopes.Name: Titanium-47
Isotopes.Use: Industrial alloys, Aerospace, Medical implants, NMR

Isotopes.Name: Titanium-48
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant titanium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Titanium-49
Isotopes.Use: Industrial alloys, Aerospace, Medical implants, NMR

Isotopes.Name: Titanium-50
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁵⁰V with a half-life > 4×10¹⁷ y.

Isotopes.Name: Vanadium-50
Isotopes.Notes: Primordial radioisotope. Only naturally occurring isotope of any element to decay by two different modes (EC and β⁻).

Isotopes.Name: Vanadium-51
Isotopes.Use: Alloys (e.g., steel), Vanadium redox batteries, NMR
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant vanadium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Chromium-50
Isotopes.Notes: Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁵⁰Ti with a half-life > 1.3×10¹⁸ y.

Isotopes.Name: Chromium-52
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant chromium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Chromium-53
Isotopes.Use: Alloys, Protective coatings, Scientific research, NMR

Isotopes.Name: Chromium-54
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁵⁴Fe with a half-life > 4.4×10¹⁸ y.

Isotopes.Name: Manganese-52
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Radiotracer, Experimental PET/MRI imaging

Isotopes.Name: Iron-52
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, ⁵²Mn generator for PET imaging

Isotopes.Name: Iron-54
Isotopes.Notes: Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁵⁴Cr with a half-life > 4.4×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Iron-56
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant iron isotope. Has the lowest mass per nucleon of all nuclides, but not the highest binding energy per nucleon (which belongs to ⁶²Ni).

Isotopes.Name: Iron-57
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Widely used in Mössbauer spectroscopy.

Isotopes.Name: Iron-58
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁵⁸Ni with a half-life > 4.9×10²² y.

Isotopes.Name: Iron-59
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Radiotracer (e.g., in metabolism studies)

Isotopes.Name: Iron-60
Isotopes.Notes: Extinct radionuclide. Its presence in meteorites provides evidence for supernova nucleosynthesis in the early solar system.

Isotopes.Name: Cobalt-56
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Calibration source, Supernova light curve studies
Isotopes.Notes: Responsible for the long-term light curve of Type Ia supernovae.

Isotopes.Name: Cobalt-57
Isotopes.Use: Medical diagnostics (e.g., Schilling test), Mössbauer spectroscopy source, Calibration source

Isotopes.Name: Cobalt-59
Isotopes.Use: Alloys (e.g., magnets, high-strength alloys), Batteries, Pigments (Cobalt blue)

Isotopes.Name: Cobalt-60
Isotopes.Use: Medical radiation therapy, Industrial radiography, Food irradiation, Sterilization, Calibration source
Isotopes.Notes: Strong gamma ray emitter. Used in the Wu experiment demonstrating parity violation.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-48
Isotopes.Notes: Lightest known nickel isotope. Exhibits double magic properties.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-56
Isotopes.Notes: Double magic nucleus. Produced in large quantities in Type Ia supernovae; its decay to ⁵⁶Co and then to ⁵⁶Fe powers the light curve.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-58
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant nickel isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁵⁸Fe with a half-life > 7×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-59
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research (cosmogenic nuclide), Nuclear reactor studies

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-60
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Final decay product of ⁶⁰Fe and ⁶⁰Co.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-61
Isotopes.Use: Alloys, Stainless steel, Scientific research, NMR

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-62
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Has the highest binding energy per nucleon of any known nuclide (8.7946 MeV/nucleon).

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-63
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Electron capture detectors, Batteries

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-64
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁶⁴Zn with a half-life > 2.3×10¹⁸ y.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-68
Isotopes.Notes: Considered 'semi-magic' due to the N=40 subshell closure.

Isotopes.Name: Nickel-78
Isotopes.Notes: Double magic nucleus (28 protons, 50 neutrons). Important for astrophysical r-process.

Isotopes.Name: Copper-62
Isotopes.Notes: Used in PET imaging, often from a ⁶²Zn generator.

Isotopes.Name: Copper-63
Isotopes.Use: Electrical wiring, Plumbing, Coins, Alloys (e.g., brass, bronze)
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant copper isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Copper-65
Isotopes.Use: Electrical wiring, Plumbing, Coins, Alloys (e.g., brass, bronze)

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-62
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, ⁶²Cu generator for PET imaging

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-64
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant zinc isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁶⁴Ni with a half-life > 2.3×10¹⁸ y.

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-68
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Used to produce ⁶⁷Cu.

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-69
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁶⁹ᵐZn (T½ = 13.76 h).

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-70
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁷⁰Ge with a half-life > 1.3×10¹⁴ y.

Isotopes.Name: Zinc-71
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁷¹ᵐZn (T½ = 3.96 h).

Isotopes.Name: Gallium-67
Isotopes.Use: Medical imaging (SPECT) for tumors and infections

Isotopes.Name: Gallium-68
Isotopes.Use: PET imaging (e.g., neuroendocrine tumors), often from ⁶⁸Ge generator

Isotopes.Name: Gallium-69
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant gallium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Germanium-68
Isotopes.Use: Source for ⁶⁸Ga PET imaging generators (Gallopet)
Isotopes.Notes: Parent isotope for medical ⁶⁸Ga generators.

Isotopes.Name: Germanium-70
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁷⁰Zn with a half-life > 4.1×10²² y.

Isotopes.Name: Germanium-71
Isotopes.Notes: Product of neutrino capture by ⁷¹Ga.

Isotopes.Name: Germanium-74
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant germanium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Germanium-76
Isotopes.Use: Neutrinoless double beta decay searches (e.g., GERDA, MAJORANA)
Isotopes.Notes: Primordial radioisotope. Observationally stable, but undergoes double beta decay.

Isotopes.Name: Arsenic-74
Isotopes.Use: Scientific research, Radiotracer, Experimental PET imaging

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-73
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁷³ᵐSe (T½ = 39.8 min).

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-74
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁷⁴Ge with a half-life > 3.4×10²¹ y.

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-75
Isotopes.Use: Medical imaging (scintigraphy), Industrial radiography (gamma source), Radiotracer

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-76
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁷⁶Kr with a half-life > 2.0×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-78
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁷⁸Kr with a half-life > 1.1×10²¹ y.

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-79
Isotopes.Notes: Long-lived fission product. Has a metastable isomer ⁷⁹ᵐSe (T½ = 3.92 min).

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-80
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant selenium isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁸⁰Kr with a half-life > 1.6×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-81
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸¹ᵐSe (T½ = 57.28 min).

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-82
Isotopes.Use: Neutrinoless double beta decay searches (e.g., NEMO, SuperNEMO)
Isotopes.Notes: Primordial radioisotope. Observationally stable, but undergoes double beta decay.

Isotopes.Name: Selenium-83
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸³ᵐSe (T½ = 70.1 s).

Isotopes.Name: Bromine-80
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁰ᵐBr (T½ = 4.4205 h).

Isotopes.Name: Bromine-82
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸²ᵐBr (T½ = 6.13 min).

Name: Krypton

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-78
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁷⁸Se with a half-life > 1.1×10²¹ y.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-79
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁷⁹ᵐKr (T½ = 50 s).

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-80
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁸⁰Se with a half-life > 6.0×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-81
Isotopes.Use: Medical imaging (V/Q scan), Radiometric dating (Krypton-81 dating)
Isotopes.Notes: Cosmogenic radionuclide. Used for dating old groundwater.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-82
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁸²Se with a half-life > 1.1×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-83
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Has a metastable isomer ⁸³ᵐKr (T½ = 1.83 h) used in medical imaging.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-84
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant krypton isotope. Used in the original definition of the meter.

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-85
Isotopes.Use: Industrial gauging, Radiotracer, Nuclear fuel reprocessing monitoring
Isotopes.Notes: Fission product. Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁵ᵐKr (T½ = 4.48 h).

Isotopes.Name: Krypton-86
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Its spectral line was used for the definition of the meter from 1960 to 1983.

Abundance: O: 1.1 ppt | A: 1.1 ppm | U: 0.5 ppm

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-78
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁷⁸ᵐRb (T½ = 5.74 min).

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-81
Isotopes.Notes: Parent isotope for ⁸¹ᵐKr generators used in lung ventilation scans.

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-82
Isotopes.Notes: Used for myocardial perfusion PET imaging, produced from a ⁸²Sr generator.

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-84
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁴ᵐRb (T½ = 20.26 min).

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-85
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant rubidium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-87
Isotopes.Use: Rubidium-strontium dating, Atomic clocks, Bose-Einstein condensates
Isotopes.Notes: Primordial radioisotope. Used extensively in geologic dating.

Isotopes.Name: Rubidium-90
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁹⁰ᵐRb (T½ = 258 s).

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-82
Isotopes.Use: Parent isotope for ⁸²Rb generators (cardiac PET scans)

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-84
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁺β⁺ decay to ⁸⁴Kr with a half-life > 3.2×10²² y.

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-85
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁵ᵐSr (T½ = 67.63 min).

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-86
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Used as a reference in Sr isotope geology.

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-87
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Radiogenic product of ⁸⁷Rb decay, forming the basis for Rb-Sr dating.

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-88
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant strontium isotope.

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-89
Isotopes.Use: Medical therapy (palliative care for bone cancer metastases)

Isotopes.Name: Strontium-90
Isotopes.Use: Radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTGs), Industrial gauges, Medical therapy
Isotopes.Notes: High-yield fission product. Biologically significant as it mimics calcium and accumulates in bones. Decays to ⁹⁰Y, which is also radioactive.

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-86
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁶ᵐY (T½ = 48 min).

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-87
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁷ᵐY (T½ = 13.38 h).

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-88
Isotopes.Use: Gamma ray calibration source, ⁹⁰Y generator parent

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-89
Isotopes.Notes: Only stable isotope of yttrium. Magic neutron number (N=50).

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-90
Isotopes.Notes: Used in cancer therapy (e.g., Zevalin). Daughter product of ⁹⁰Sr.

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-91
Isotopes.Notes: Fission product. Has a metastable isomer ⁹¹ᵐY (T½ = 49.71 min).

Isotopes.Name: Yttrium-97
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁹⁷ᵐY (T½ = 1.17 s).

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-89
Isotopes.Notes: Has a metastable isomer ⁸⁹ᵐZr (T½ = 4.161 min).

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-90
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Most abundant zirconium isotope. Magic neutron number (N=50).

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-92
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁹²Mo with a half-life > 1.2×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-94
Isotopes.Notes: Stable isotope. Observationally stable, but predicted to undergo β⁻β⁻ decay to ⁹⁴Mo with a half-life > 1.4×10²⁰ y.

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-95
Isotopes.Notes: Common fission product, often used with ⁹⁵Nb as a tracer.

Isotopes.Name: Zirconium-96
Isotopes.Use: Nuclear reactors (Zircaloy), Alloys, Double beta decay searches
Isotopes.Notes: Primordial radioisotope. Observationally stable, but undergoes double beta decay.

Isotopes.Name: Niobium-89
